repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: Neovim-specific highlight groups in `:h treesitter-highlight-groups` and `:h lsp-semantic-highlight` are not previewed like the legacy syntax groups in `:h highlight-groups`. Also highlight the list of default (syntax) highlight groups in `syntax.txt` , as a treat.

Solution: Refactor the `vimhelp.lua` script and apply it to those files as well.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
-- Called when editing doc/syntax.txt doc/lsp.txt doc/treesitter.txt files
```
I don't want to copy-paste the same `stop` pattern every time there's a change, so consider creating a variable.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,6 +2,27 @@
 vim.treesitter.start()
 
 -- add custom highlights for list in `:h highlight-groups`
-if vim.endswith(vim.fs.normalize(vim.api.nvim_buf_get_name(0)), '/doc/syntax.txt') then
-  require('vim.vimhelp').highlight_groups()
+local bufname = vim.fs.normalize(vim.api.nvim_buf_get_name(0))
+if vim.endswith(bufname, '/doc/syntax.txt') then
+  require('vim.vimhelp').highlight_groups({
+    { start = [[\*group-name\*]], stop = '^======', match = '^(%w+)\t' },

comment_data.body: I believe new types should be as strict as possible. That is, the type of `patterns` should specify the keys and respective value types. This yields better completion and diagnostic support.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,26 +2,26 @@
 
 local M = {}
 
--- Called when editing the doc/syntax.txt file
-function M.highlight_groups()
-  local save_cursor = vim.fn.getcurpos()
-
-  local start_lnum = vim.fn.search([[\*highlight-groups\*]], 'c')
-  if start_lnum == 0 then
-    return
-  end
-  local end_lnum = vim.fn.search('^======')
-  if end_lnum == 0 then
-    return
-  end
-
+-- apply current colorscheme to lists of default highlight groups
+---@param patterns table[] {start, stop, match} assumed to be sorted by start!

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- Apply current colorscheme to lists of default highlight groups
```
Why not make this part of the public documentation?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,26 +2,26 @@

--- Called when editing the doc/syntax.txt file

comment_data.body: If there will ever be a change, it won't necessarily be the same for all `stop` patterns.

+  require('vim.vimhelp').highlight_groups({
+    { start = [[\*group-name\*]], stop = '^======', match = '^(%w+)\t' },

comment_data.body: Fair point, but given that these represent section delimiters I do forecast some consistency (even in the event of change). I'm just not a fan of random string literals, but I won't die on a hill for this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,6 +2,27 @@

+    { start = [[\*group-name\*]], stop = '^======', match = '^(%w+)\t' },

comment_data.body: They _are_ random, though; they just happen to be the same in half the cases here (and could even be tightened up in some of them, which I've thought about doing).

comment_data.body: As this is not a proper AP (and certainly not meant to be used publicly), I didn't even plan on adding any... Feel free to suggest a proper type annotation, and I'll include it.

comment_data.body:
Because it wasn't meant to be public documentation ;)

We can certainly _make_ it public if plugins want to show off their highlight groups (via a filetype autocommand)?

comment_data.body: But you're right, the annotation should be correct or not at all. I've removed it for now; if someone wants to promote it to a public API in a followup, a proper docstring (and validation, and whatnot) can be added.

comment_regular_data.body: I think that's all of them (except for the `Nvim*` groups from the legacy expression parser -- to be replaced by treesitter -- and builtin plugins).

But the (your?) function requires that. It's also consistent with the other list in `syntax.txt`. I think the color outweighs the ragged right (and I can always add padding _after_ the highlight groups).
No, you can put the part of the pattern that matches the indent outside the capture group.
But then we should indent _all_ of these lists.
For treesitter doc, I think it could be not indented to some day also upstream nvim-treesitter's `CONTRIBUTING.md` docs on how certain captures are used?

title: docs: highlight treesitter and lsp  groups
